title: TEMPERAMENT & ENERGY PROFILE
description: Phase 0 Bead 2: Analyze introversion/extroversion. Stress tolerance. Autonomy needs. Tolerance for monotony vs novelty. Focus on how David actually operates day to day.

comments.author: mayor
comments.text:
## TEMPERAMENT PROFILE

**Introversion/Extroversion:** Strong introvert
- Solitary activities central (walking, reading, writing)
- Family time valued, not broad social engagement
- Quaker practice reinforces contemplative disposition
- Needs significant alone time to function

**Stress Tolerance:** Low to moderate
- Explicit desire for balance and slowness
- Aversion to escalating demands
- Chronic stress likely corrosive to wellbeing

**Autonomy Needs:** High
- Wants part-time, independent, self-directed work
- Control over pace essential (work into old age)
- Poor fit for managed or supervised roles

**Monotony vs. Novelty:** High tolerance for repetition
- Values repeatability
- Daily practices (walking, reading, writing) are inherently routine
- Quaker tradition values faithful consistency
- Low novelty-seeking

**Daily Operation Pattern:**
- Likely steady pacer, not burst worker
- Deep focus over multitasking
- Physical movement needed throughout day
- Fatigued by interruption-heavy environments
- Recovery time needed after social or complex work

title: VALUES & NON-NEGOTIABLES
description: Phase 0 Bead 1: Identify core values (max 7). Identify hard constraints (financial, health, temperament). Identify explicit dealbreakers.

comments.author: mayor
comments.text:
## VALUES (7)
1. Simplicity — Minimal possessions, obligations, complexity
2. Integrity — Quaker testimony; work that doesn't compromise conscience  
3. Peace — Non-violent, non-exploitative work; calm environment
4. Care — Attention to people, not abstractions; service over extraction
5. Balance — Work/rest, family/solitude, body/mind equilibrium
6. Presence — Being where you are; not optimizing for elsewhere
7. Continuity — Work and life sustainable into old age

## HARD CONSTRAINTS
- US residence required
- Income needed (not zero, but lifestyle > salary)
- Physical capacity for walking, manual work — preserve this
- No relocation to high-cost metros
- Must allow part-time or independent structure eventually

## DEALBREAKERS
- High screen intensity (8+ hours/day computer work)
- Automotive/mechanical work (explicitly disliked)
- Prestige-driven or hustle culture environments
- Work requiring constant availability or on-call
- Work that scales up rather than down over time
- Work misaligned with Quaker testimonies (weapons, extraction, manipulation)

title: SKILLS & LEVERAGE
description: Phase 0 Bead 3: Inventory usable skills and credentials. Identify which skills support simplicity and which undermine it. Identify assets worth preserving vs abandoning.

comments.author: mayor
comments.text:
## SKILLS INVENTORY

| Skill | Credential | Supports Simplicity | Undermines Simplicity |
|-------|------------|---------------------|----------------------|
| IT/Software | Experience | Income leverage | High screen, tech dependency |
| Baking | Practice | Physical, embodied, low-tech | Early hours, physical stamina |
| Automotive | Experience | — | Explicitly disliked |
| Accounting | Degree | Part-time viable, credential | Can become complex |
| Writing | Practice | Solitary, low-tech, creative | Low income |

## PRESERVE (leverage for life goals)
- **Accounting credential** — Bookkeeping for small businesses is low-screen, part-time friendly, scalable down
- **Baking skills** — Physical, embodied, community-oriented. Farmers market, small bakery, home-based
- **Writing practice** — Supports inner life. Could enable tutoring, editing, small freelance

## USE STRATEGICALLY (not as primary)
- **IT/Software** — High income but high cost to simplicity. Targeted consulting only to build savings, then phase out

## ABANDON
- **Automotive work** — Explicit dislike. No further consideration.

## LATENT ASSETS
- Quaker community membership — network for simple-living opportunities
- Introvert temperament — suited for focused, solitary work
- Reading/intellectual capacity — could support education-adjacent work
